tossups.question: A police commissioner in this city claimed that he would best Attila the Hun with harsh police tactics against an organization that followed “The Guidelines,” a manifesto dictated to Donald Glassey. Cecil B. Moore employed picketing to desegregate this city’s Girard College. Daisy Myers was praised as the “Rosa Parks of the North” for moving into a community in this city. This city’s first black mayor ordered a 1985 (*) bombing against MOVE in it. Richard Allen’s original AME church was mapped out in W.E.B. DuBois’ study of this city’s “Negro.” Benjamin Rush mistakenly concluded that this city’s black people were immune to yellow fever during a 1793 epidemic. For 10 points, name this northern city where the Declaration of Independence was signed.
tossups.answer: Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (the police commissioner in the first line is Frank Rizzo)

tossups.question: In one poem, Gary Snyder wrote that Philip Whalen had "built a poem" to this man and that the "drunkard [had] taught him how to dance." A poem titled "Thinking of" this poet "at the End of the Sky" asks "what thoughts occupy the gentleman's mind?" and "what time will the wild goose come?" One translation of this poet describes how the title character "played about the front gate, pulling flowers" when her husband returned and remembers "When my (*) hair was cut straight across my forehead.” That poem was translated as "The River Merchant's Wife: A Letter" by Ezra Pound. This poet wrote "A cup of wine, under the flowering trees" in "Drinking Alone by Moonlight." For 10 points, name this poet, who with Wang Wei and Du Fu, is among the most celebrated poets of the Tang Dynasty.
tossups.answer: Li Bai [or Li Po; or Rihaku]

tossups.question: They’re not camelids, but these animals produce IgNAR (“I-G-N-A-R”), a novel heavy-chain antibody. Steroidal saponins, such as pavoninin-1, are potent secretions that evolved as natural repellents against these animals. These animals possess both a muscularized conus arteriosus chamber in their hearts and an unfused palatoquadrate bone. These animals are the largest in their clade to possess a (*) corkscrew-shaped modification to their large intestine called the spiral valve. Large numbers of calcium and potassium receptors provide the basis for a unique electroreceptive organ in these stiff-body swimming animals called the ampullae of Lorenzini. For 10 points, name these animals exemplified by the hammerhead and great white.
tossups.answer: sharks [prompt on cartilaginous fish or Chondrichthyes or Elasmobranchs; accept Selachimorpha or words forms; accept any specific species of shark; do not accept rays, skates, or other non-sharks or any answers mentioning camels or llamas] (IgNAR stands for new-antigen receptor)

tossups.question: Note to moderator: read the notes slowly. A Toccata for this instrument and organ originally attributed to Frescobaldi was actually composed by Gaspar Cassadó. A popular edition of a set of works for this instrument was edited by August Wenzinger for Bärenreiter. This is the most common instrument that employs a wolf-tone eliminator. Friedrich Grützmacher arranged several concertos for this instrument by Luigi (*) Boccherini (“BAHK-eh-REE-nee”). A solo work for this instrument in G major opens with the ascending arpeggiated notes “G, D, B.” A set of suites for this solo instrument all open with a prelude and end with a gigue (“zheeg”) - those six suites were popularized in the 1930’s by Pablo Casals. For 10 points, J.S. Bach composed six suites for what string instrument played by Yo-Yo Ma?
tossups.answer: cello [or violoncello; DO NOT accept or prompt on “violin”]

tossups.question: This work argues that the frequent use of the word “definitions” in books on logic and math has given it a "dangerously reassuring sound." One section of this work claims that abandoning its central concepts would result in "a blurring of the supposed boundary between speculative metaphysics and natural science". This work establishes the idea of cognitive synonymy in a section that argues against the verification theory. This work contrasts its central concepts with the difference between "no (*) unmarried man is married" and "no bachelor is married." This work's title references the concepts of reductionism and the analytic-synthetic divide. For 10 points, name this paper critiquing logical positivism, written by W.V.O. Quine.
tossups.answer: “Two Dogmas of Empiricism”

tossups.question: The Nash-Williams theorem provides conditions for which one of these objects is k-arboric. The Bron-Kerbosch algorithm uses a pivot point to minimize the number of recursive calls while finding the maximum number of cliques “clicks” on one of these objects. Adjacency lists are more space-efficient representations than adjacency matrices when these objects are termed “sparse”. A classic NP-indeterminate problem asks whether one of these objects is (*) isomorphic to another one of them. A big-O of E-log-E runtime algorithm named for Kruskal iteratively connects segments of increasing edge weights to generate a minimum spanning tree on one of these objects. For 10 points, name these constructs consisting of vertices connected by edges.
tossups.answer: graphs

tossups.question: An activist for these people was killed while washing his car after discovering thousands of mass graves of these people resulting from “fake encounters”. A.S. Vaidya was assassinated for masterminding an attack on these people that resulted in Jarnail Bhindranwale’s death. The deadliest Canadian airplane bombing was perpetrated by these people in retribution for a 1984 genocide against them. Support for an independent state of (*) Khalistan among these people rose after Operation Blue Star. Two of these people killed Indira Gandhi while serving as her bodyguards. The Golden Temple was invaded by the Indian government during a celebration of these people’s fifth Guru. For 10 points, name these people, easily recognized by their turbans.
tossups.answer: Sikhs [prompt on Punjabis until “1984 genocide” (the activist in the first line is Jaswant Singh Kalra]

tossups.question: Chinese ceramics damaged in shipping were intentionally incorporated as outdoor signposts for one building with this name. That building with this name features door frames topped by irregular hexagons, several rooms lined with “origami chairs,” and a downward-sloping cabaret with nearly perfect acoustics. Another building with this name was constructed from yellow (*) limestone and golden-sheened plaster to resemble the banks of a nearby river. That building of this name was designed after its architect left his Oak Park studio, had to be reconstructed after it was burnt down by a disgruntled servant, and was named for resembling the “shining brow” of a hill. For 10 points, give this Welsh-inspired name of Frank Lloyd Wright’s homes in Arizona and Wisconsin.
tossups.answer: Taliesin [accept Taliesin West or Taliesin East]

tossups.question: This text's threefold form begins with a section titled for "Innumerable Meanings." This text describes the fight of "justice against evil" according to an essay titled for the "Wisdom of" this text by Daisaku Ikedu. Zhiyi's (“jer-ee’s”) writings on this text led to the founding of the Tiantai school, which venerates this text. The organization Soka Gakkai venerates this text, whose title is rendered as (*) "Nam Myoho Renge Kyo" (“NAM MYO-ho REN-gay KYO”) by followers of Nichiren. This text demonstrates upaya, or expedient means, in a section where a father offers his sons various carts to save them from the title structure. That section is the "Parable of the Burning House." For 10 points, name this Mahayana sutra, named for a sacred flower.
tossups.answer: Lotus Sutra [or Saddharma Puṇḍarīka Sutra; accept Namu Myoho Renge Kyo before mentioned]

tossups.question: This character grabs ahold of a man’s hair which then turns into a comet and carries this character through a “rarefied and glacial atmosphere." This character sees a war between cars and humans and re-experiences his relationships with Emma and Rosa. At the end of the novel in which this character appears, he watches as a murdered prostitute is picked up and placed in the pocket of a (*) jazz musician. On his fiftieth birthday, this character learns the foxtrot from Hermine. Near the beginning of the novel he appears in, this character finds a pamphlet labeled "FOR MADMEN ONLY.” For 10 points, name this protagonist of a Herman Hesse novel, nicknamed for his lupine appearance.
tossups.answer: Harry Haller [or Harry Haller; accept Der Steppenwolf]

tossups.question: Hindered inversions of this quantity characterize a new form of stereoisomer given the prefixes “parvo-” and “amplo-” based on a 2018 study of bridged porphyrin molecules. The concentration of atomic character toward electropositive substituents may contribute to deviations in this quantity according to Bent’s rule. For carbonyl reactions, one form of this quantity that fully characterizes the nucleophilic attack is named for (*) Burgi and Dunitz. In VSEPR theory, replacing a substituent group with an electron pair leads to a reduction in this quantity. For cyclic molecules, deviations in this quantity from ideality cause ring strain to occur. For 10 points, name this quantity that is roughly 104.5 degrees for a water molecule.
tossups.answer: bond angle [prompt on angle alone; anti-prompt (“Be less specific…”) on “dihedral angle” or “torsion angle” or “angle of attack”]

tossups.question: The remastered 2004 version of this band’s best-selling album added a song that includes the lyrics “time cast a spell on you, but you won’t forget me.” A leg of lamb and a Kleenex box are among the percussion instruments this band used in a song recorded with the USC marching band. A song by this band says the title woman “rings like a bell through the night” and asks “Would you stay if she promised you (*) heaven?”. Another of this band’s songs opens with the line “Listen to the wind blow” and claims “I can still hear you saying / You will never break” the title object. Christine McVie and Lindsey Buckingham’s failing relationships influenced their 1977 album Rumours. For 10 points, name this band whose songs “Rhiannon” and “The Chain” were recorded by Stevie Nicks.
tossups.answer: Fleetwood Mac [the song in the first line is “Silver Springs”]

tossups.question: When besieged by this ruler, the citizens of Ephesus attached a 4,000-foot long rope from the city walls to a statue of Artemis to seek the goddess’ protection. The Oracle of Delphi told this son of Alyattes that he would rule until the Medes had a mule for a king. A dream that this ruler’s son would die of an iron spear came after a conversation about the athletes Cleobis and Biton with (*) Solon. An ambiguous statement from the Oracle of Delphi about an empire’s destruction prompted this ruler to lead an ill-advised attack at the Battle of Thymbra. This ruler’s capital of Sardis was captured after a siege by Cyrus the Great. According to Herodotus, this ruler was the first to strike coins in gold and silver. For 10 points, name this final ruler of Lydia, legendary for his wealth.
tossups.answer: Croesus of Lydia

tossups.question: A character created by this author attempts to sell tapestries given to her husband’s family by Louis XV (“the fifteenth”). In another novel by this author, a character sends his wife lilies-of-the-valley and another woman yellow roses. This author created a character who divorces the aristocrat Raymond de Chelles to remarry the newly rich Elmer Moffatt. A novel by this author opens at an (*) opera that Mrs. Manson Mingott is too obese to attend, and ends 25 years later when its protagonist sits on a bench instead of visiting his former love interest. This author targeted Manhattan society in a novel in which May announces her pregnancy, ending the romance between Ellen Olenska and Newland Archer. For 10 points, name this author of The Custom of the County and The Age of Innocence.
tossups.answer: Edith Wharton

tossups.question: This psychologist built on the work of George Herbert Mead by arguing that the "I" was an indivisible unit of identity, as compared to the "me" which could be divided into the material, social, and spiritual self. This psychologist created four maxims of habit, which he argued was the central mechanism of education. This psychologist criticized the conception of thoughts as independent entities, instead advocating for the (*) "stream of consciousness," while in another book distinguished the "healthy-mind" from the "sick soul." Along with Carl Lange, this psychologist names a theory of emotion which states that emotions are the result of outside stimulus. For 10 points, name this psychologist, the author of Principles of Psychology, who also wrote Pragmatism.
tossups.answer: William James

tossups.question: A woman at one of these events has white cheeks “mingled” with “streaks of red” and has a chin that was stung by a bee. Alfred, Lord Tennyson recounts one of these events in the epilogue to his poem “In Memoriam A.H.H.” Each stanza in a poem about one of these events ends by saying “Sweet Thames, run softly, till I end my song.” A character named for one of these events became a (*) “sadder and wiser man” at the poem’s end. Edmund Spenser wrote about these events in poems titled “Prothalamion” and “Epithalamion.” A “guest” at one of these events listens to the title character’s story about a sailor in Samuel Taylor Coleridge’s “Rime of the Ancient Mariner.” For 10 points, name these events where love poems are often recited before making vows.
tossups.answer: weddings [or marriages; or nuptials; the first sentence is about Sir John Suckling’s “Ballad Upon a Wedding”]

tossups.question: The first president of this country served only five days before being assassinated by an insane art critic at the Zacheta Art Gallery. It’s not Greece, but this country’s “Colonels’ Regime” followed a period during which the Sanation movement promoted a union of states called an “Intermarium”. At the Battle of Monte Cassino, this country’s armed forces employed a (*) bear. This country signed the Treaty of Riga with a larger neighbor after emerging victorious from the “Miracle on the Vistula”. Marshal Jozef Pilsudski dominated this country’s politics during the interwar period. For 10 points, name this country, which was invaded on September 1, 1939, by Germany to begin World War II.
tossups.answer: Republic of Poland (the first president mentioned was Gabriel Narutowicz)

tossups.question: These systems name a technique used in FT-ICR in which a mass spectrometer’s vacuum chamber is heated to increase vibrational fragmentations. One of these systems is responsible for the glow seen in solids above the Draper point. The flux emitted by one of these systems is described in the Sakuma-Hattori equation. A constant equal to 2897 micrometers-Kelvin is divided by absolute temperature to describe the (*) spectral radiance of one of these systems. Describing one of these systems with the equipartition theorem led to the first description of the ultraviolet catastrophe. The total energy of these systems is proportional to the 4th power of temperature by the Stefan-Boltzmann law. For 10 points, name these perfect absorbers of incoming radiation.
tossups.answer: (ideal) blackbody (radiation) (The first line refers to BIRD-Blackbody Infrared Radiative Dissociation; the power-break clue is Wien’s displacement law)

tossups.question: Jonathan Zarecki linked this object and its owner to the “good” version of Eris, who he argues introduced manual labor to mankind. Book 24 of the Iliad alludes to this object and its counterpart next to the throne of Zeus, from which he fills “the cup of mortal man.” The name of a goddess associated with this object, Elpis, is sometimes translated as the “expectation of bad” despite changing connotations in other accounts. Despite the colloquial translation of this object’s name, this object was actually a (*) pithos. In some accounts, this object was opened by its owner’s husband, Epimetheus, releasing all of its contents except hope. For 10 points, name this item owned by the first woman in Greek mythology, containing all the world’s vices.
tossups.answer: Pandora’s box [accept any answers indicating a container-like object belonging to Pandora]

tossups.question: One unusual portrait of a holder of this political position is simply a black shroud with the Latin inscription “beheaded for his crimes”. Palma Giovane depicted a holder of this position being bestowed with a laurel wreath by two angels with interlocked arms. In an unusually fierce portrait of a holder of this position, that figure’s hand is in a pose evoking the hand of Michelangelo’s horned Moses. (*) 76 portraits of holders of this position can be found in the Sala del Maggior Consiglio alongside Tintoretto’s Paradise. Holders of this office are traditionally depicted wearing a corno hat, and Giovanni Bellini painted several portraits of this office’s holders. For 10 points, name this political position whose past holders can be seen in portraits throughout Venice’s Ducal Palace.
tossups.answer: Doge of Venice [prompt on generic answers like “ruler of Venice”]

bonuses.leadin: In this play, Ernst says he loves Hanschen “as I have never loved a soul” after they share a kiss. For 10 points each:
answers: August Strindberg (the play is Miss Julie)
parts: Name this dark German play which contains a scene where Melchior takes advantage of Wendla in a hayloft. Some of its themes were made lighter for a 21st-century Broadway musical.

In the original production of Spring Awakening, a man named for wearing one of these objects leaves with Melchior at the play’s end. One of these objects disguises the identity of the title character of Gaston Leroux’s The Phantom of the Opera.

Spring Awakening author Frank Wedekind had a child with Frida Uhl, the ex-wife of this other playwright. He wrote a play which ends with the title character walking outside with a razor after Jean orders her to kill herself.

bonuses.leadin: This ballet premiered at Paris’ Theatre du Chatelet with costumes and set designed by Pablo Picasso and Giacomo Balla. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this one-act ballet by Jean Cocteau with choreography by Léonide Massine. This ballet’s plot concerns three groups of circus performers at the title public spectacle.
This French composer collaborated with Cocteau to write the music for Parade. Piano pieces by this composer include his collaboration with Alexander Calder, Socrate, and his 3 Gymnopedies.

Picasso and Massine also collaborated to design the sets, costumes, and choreography for this other ballet with music by Manuel de Falla. This ballet’s second act opens with a “dance of the neighbors”, and its 1st Act includes a notable fandango by the Miller’s wife.

bonuses.leadin: These campaigns are sometimes called the “Ceramic Wars” because potters were kidnapped and moved to Arita, where they developed one country’s porcelain industry. For 10 points each:
answers: Japanese invasions of Korea [accept Hideyoshi’s invasions of Korea; accept Imjin Wars]
Admiral Yi Sun-shin (“EE sun-SHIN”) [or Yi Sun-sin]
parts: Name these campaigns during which soldiers reportedly cut off the noses of their victims as trophies because heads were too unwieldy to haul around.

Hideyoshi’s invasions of Korea failed due to the efforts of this naval commander under Korea’s King Seonjo. This general died at the Battle of Noryang, but not before developing ironclad turtle ships.
Toyotomi Hideyoshi died during his last invasion of Korea, paving the way for this man to found his namesake shogunate after his victory at Sekigahara.

bonuses.leadin: According to one theorem, particles with this quantum mechanical property will have symmetric wavefunctions under exchange interaction. For 10 points each:
answers: integer spin [prompt on spin alone; prompt on bosons with “what type of spin do they possess?”; do not accept or prompt on “half-integer spin”]
parts: Name this property that, according to the same theorem, describes particles that are not subject to the Pauli exclusion principle. Particles with this property follow Bose-Einstein statistics.
In contrast to the integer spins of bosons, these particles are defined as having half-integer spins. These particles’ namesake co-names a distribution of energy states with Paul Dirac.

According to this theorem, if a system has a half-integer spin, then every energy eigenstate of its Hamiltonian must be at least doubly degenerate. This theorem also requires that the system is time-reversible and symmetric.

bonuses.leadin: One character quips “As Montesquieu wrote a Spirit of Laws, so could I write a Spirit of [these things]”, after earlier observing that “little or nothing” had been written on their philosophy or history. For 10 points each:
answers: Clothes, Their Origin and Influence [accept word forms like clothing or costumes]
parts: Name these things. They are the subject of the best-known work by Diogenes Teufelsdrockh, a fictional character in a Thomas Carlyle novel.
Carlyle’s Sartor Resartus was heavily influenced by this satire by Jonathan Swift about Peter, Martin, and Jack, who represent different churches.
Dr. Watson expresses shock that Sherlock Holmes is not familiar with the works of Thomas Carlyle in this author’s novel A Study in Scarlet.

bonuses.leadin: A dissected view of one of these musical instruments can be seen below vertical rows of sheet music and a palette in one work, and an even more fragmented one rests below a pitcher in another painting. For 10 points each:
answers: violin(s) [accept Violin and Palette, Violin and Pitcher, or Violin and Candlestick]
Cubism [or word forms, such as Cubist]
parts: Name these musical instruments. One of them is shown in earthen tones and surrounded by common still-life props, such as a candlestick, in a later painting by the same artist.
Those fragmented depictions of violins are works by Georges Braque, who along with Pablo Picasso, founded this art movement with “synthetic” and “analytic” branches.

The name of the Cubist movement comes from a comment made by critic Louis Vauxcelles (“voh-sell”) mocking an early painting by Braque depicting some houses in this French village, which Vauxcelles described as “little cubes”.

bonuses.leadin: Stanford University’s Wilcox Observatory collects daily measurements about the strength, relative position, and polar orientation of this entity. For 10 points each:
answers: the sun’s magnetic field [prompt on partial answers]
Richard Christopher Carrington [accept Carrington rotation or Carrington Rotation Number]
parts: Name this astronomical entity. Interactions with solar wind cause this entity to adopt a twisted shape known as the Parker spiral.

Data from the Wilcox observatory uses a numbering system based on the unit of solar rotation named for this scientist to track the sun’s magnetic field, which is roughly equal to 27.27 earth days. At the time of writing this bonus, the sun was at number 2223 in those units named for this scientist.

A benefit of the Carrington system is that it allows for easy tracking of these regions of reduced solar surface temperature. They occur in roughly 11-year cycles and are most common when the sun’s magnetic field flips.

bonuses.leadin: In The American Dream and the Public Schools, Jennifer L. Hochschild and Nathan Scovronick promoted this movement, claiming that the institutions central to it have been demonstrated to “help disadvantaged children achieve, just as they enable middle-class children to achieve." For 10 points each:
answers: Small Schools Movement [prompt on, but do NOT otherwise reveal answers about charter school]
Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation [or BMGF; accept William H. Gates Foundation]
parts: Name this educational movement which aims to break up schools such as the Theodore Roosevelt High School in the Bronx.

The small school movement has been largely funded by this charitable organization, the largest in the world. This organization seeks to slow population growth by increasing malaria treatments and vaccine access.

These schools were originally outgrowths of the Small School Movement. These schools receive public funding but are operated outside of the state education system and are an example of the privatization of public assets.

bonuses.leadin: This island was ruled by two consecutive kings named William named the “Bad” and the “Good”, respectively, though William the Bad was likely unfairly maligned by Hugo Falcandus. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this island. Charles of Anjou’s rule over this island ended with its namesake “Vespers”.
This Norman soldier led the conquest of Sicily, which was documented by his chronicler William of Apulia. This man defeated the forces of Alexius I Comnenus at the Battle of Dyrrhachium.
Guiscard’s ancestor, Tancred of Hauteville, played a prominent part in this military campaign. This campaign was sparked by a declaration of “Deus vult!” by Pope Urban II.

bonuses.leadin: This term refers to areas such as the Texas Triangle and the Arizona Sun Corridor. For 10 points each:
answers: megaregion [prompt on megalopolis; prompt on megapolitarian area; prompt on megacity]
Great Lakes [accept in any order Lakes Erie; Ontario; Michigan; Huron; Superior; prompt on specific great lakes]
parts: Give this term for the 11 emerging areas of increasingly connected metropolitan areas in the United States, Canada, and Mexico, which are defined by the Regional Plan Association.

The largest and most populous megaregion defined by the Regional Plan Association is named for this group of lakes on the US-Canada Border, whose shores include cities like Chicago, Detroit, and Toronto.
The cities of Portland and Seattle anchor the American part of a megaregion named for this mountain range. This volcanic mountain range includes Mt. Shasta and Mt. Hood.

bonuses.leadin: This composer’s namesake “rhythm” consists of a duplet followed immediately by a triplet or vice versa and features prominently in works such as his massive 8th symphony in C minor, subtitled Apocalyptic. For 10 points each:
answers: Berlin [accept Berlin Philharmonic or Berliner Philharmoniker]
parts: Name this Austrian Romantic composer. This devoted follower of Wagner included a Hunting Scherzo and a Volksfest finale in his fourth symphony in E-flat Major, subtitled Romantic.

Sergiu Celibidache (“CHELL-uh-bee-DOCK-ee”) notably conducted Bruckner’s Seventh Symphony upon returning to this European city’s orchestra after a 38 year absence. Famous conductors of this non-British city’s Philharmonic orchestra have included Wilhelm Furtwangler, Herbert von Karajan, and Simon Rattle.

Some Bruckner scholars have suggested that this Bruckner piece be used as a stand-in for the incomplete finale of his 9th symphony. This C major setting of a hymn for orchestra, choir, and organ, was the “pride of [Bruckner’s] life.”

bonuses.leadin: The protagonist of this story “stood trembling and tired but totally triumphant” after climbing up a pine tree. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this short story that ends with Sylvia refusing to give away the location of an animal a hunter is trying to find.

Eckels travels back in time to hunt dinosaurs, and realizes he has changed the present by accidentally stepping on a butterfly, in this author’s story “The Sound of Thunder.” He also wrote “The Veldt.”

A trip this author took to hunt big game on an African safari inspired his stories “The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber” and “The Snows of Kilimanjaro.” His other hobbies included fishing, which is fictionalized in The Old Man and the Sea.

bonuses.leadin: After the first asymmetric division in a plant’s zygote, expression of the 2nd and 8th members of a certain gene family becomes restricted to each end of this developmental axis. For 10 points each:
answers: apical-basal axis [or basal-apical axis; prompt on partial answers; do not accept any synonyms]
shoot [accept shoot apical meristem or SAM; do not accept root (apical meristem)]
auxin [prompt on indole-3-acetic acid or IAA]
parts: Name this primary axis in the plant-seed body. WUSCHEL-related HOMEOBOX genes, or WOX genes, pattern this axis similarly to how HOX genes pattern the anterior-posterior axis in animals.

WOX proteins interact with Clavata3 and Clavata1 to regulate growth of the apical meristem in this part of the plant. In botany, this region of the plant refers to the stem and all of its associated appendages.

Pin1 mutants in Arabidopsis produce few organs from their shoot apical meristem because they lack a transport protein for this hormone. Phototropism results from the unequal distribution of this hormone.

bonuses.leadin: Milkman Eric Guiney and his son Desmond were killed by rioters after this man’s death. For 10 points each:
answers: Margaret Thatcher [accept Margaret Hilda Thatcher, Baroness Thatcher]
Ian Paisley [or Iain Richard Kyle Paisley, Baron Bannside]
parts: Name this leader of a 1981 hunger strike in the Maze prison. His death inspired Patrick Magee to carry out the Brighton Hotel bombing.
Patrick Magee attempted to kill this British prime minister, also known as the “Iron Lady”.

This Irish priest campaigned against Catholics and homosexuality while leading the Free Presbyterian Church. He campaigned against the Anglo-Irish Treaty of 1985 with the memorable slogan “never, never, never!”

bonuses.leadin: According to this theory, the moral value of an action is based on mutual sympathy and a moral "sixth sense." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this theory of morality that titles a 1759 book, the first major work of the author of The Wealth of Nations.
The Theory of Moral Sentiments and The Wealth of Nations were both written by this Scottish philosopher and economist.

Adam Smith's theory of moral sentiments was heavily influenced by this Ulster-Scottish philosopher's A System of Moral Philosophy. This philosopher laid out his ideals of aesthetic uniformity in An Inquiry Into the Original of Our Ideas of Beauty and Virtue.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about new archaeology, for 10 points each:
answers: Proto-Indo-Europeans [accept Indo-Europeans; accept PIE or IE]
parts: New archaeology was founded by Willey and Phillips in their book Method and Theory in American Archaeology, which coined the phrase "archaeology is [this field] or it is nothing." This field's name translates as the "study of mankind."
This other processual archaeologist wrote the article "Archaeology as Anthropology." This archaeologist is known for applying Robert Merton's middle range theory to the field of archaeology.

Colin Renfrew, another proponent of processual anthropology, argued against Marija Gimbutas' Kurgan hypothesis for the origin of these people, instead arguing that they originated from Anatolia. The development of stop consonants in these people's language as it transitioned into Proto-Germanic is the subject of Grimm's Law.

bonuses.leadin: After this man was caned by Washington Gibbs for calling him a “renegade Confederate soldier”, a newspaper printed the headline “WAR HORSE OF YAZOO BROKE GOOD WALKING STICK OVER THE HEAD OF POPLARVILLE PERVERT.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this diminutive and extremely racist Mississippi politician who supported Marcus Garvey’s “Back to Africa” movement.

Another Congressional caning occurred before the Civil War when Preston Brooks attacked this Massachusetts Senator on the Senate floor for denouncing his father-in-law in the “Crime Against Kansas” speech.
This man caned William Stanberry for insulting his mentor Andrew Jackson. After he was defended in court by Francis Scott Key, he decided to head further South of his home state of Tennessee.

bonuses.leadin: An author from this country had her scheduled lobotomy canceled after she won a literary prize for her short story collection The Lagoon. For 10 points each:
answers: gardens [accept “The Garden Party” or “The Garden of Forking Paths”]
Eleanor Catton (that novel is The Luminaries)
parts: Name this home country of Janet Frame. A pear tree symbolizes the relationship between Bertha and Pearl in “Bliss,” a short story by an author from this country.

The author of “Bliss,” Katherine Mansfield, is more famous for a story about a “party” set in one of these locations. A Jorge Luis Borges (“BOR-hays”) story is titled for one of these places “of Forking Paths.”

This author became the youngest-ever winner of the Man Booker Prize for a novel set during the New Zealand gold rush featuring characters who correspond to the zodiac signs. She wrote the screenplay for the recent film adaptation of Jane Austen’s Emma.

bonuses.leadin: According to Bart Ehrman, this theologian's views were a "Jewish apocalyptic proclamation with a seriously Christian twist." For 10 points each:
answers: Paul the Apostle [accept Saul of Tarsus]
Law of Moses [or Mosaic Law; or Torat Moshe; accept Torah of Moses; prompt on the Law; prompt on Jewish Law or similar answers]
parts: Name this early Christian theologian, who in one letter declared "the wages of sin is death but the gift of God is eternal life" and in another letter this theologian outlined the Fruits of the Holy Spirit.

While in this city, Paul participated in an early council which produced the Apostolic Decree. This was also the city where Pontius Pilate ordered Jesus' crucifixion at Golgotha and served as the Roman capital of Judea.

The Council of Jerusalem largely rejected this body of Jewish rules, which were outlined in the Torah. In the Epistle to the Galatians, Paul rejected the position that Gentiles were required to follow these rules. These rules derive their name from a phrase inscribed at Ebal by the successor of their namesake prophet.

bonuses.leadin: Delocalized pi electrons can have a variety of effects on the stability of organic molecules. For 10 points each:
answers: antiaromaticity [do not accept or prompt on "aromaticity”]
parts: Molecules with this property have a total of 4n delocalized pi electrons in their planar ring. Molecules with this property include cyclobutadiene and the cyclopropenyl anion.
To determine whether a molecule is aromatic or antiaromatic based on it having “4n+2” or “4n” electrons, this rule can be used. This rule is named for a German chemist.

This other property describes molecules that do not have uninterrupted pi systems, but can contort themselves to create such a system. A tropylium anion with one extra ring carbon added forms a widely-studied molecule with this property.
